A vulnerability exists in which the uninitialized arelt_data->parent_cache in the _bfd_archive_close_and_cleanup function leads to a segmentation fault. This issue is related to the handling of arelt_data in pdb.c, specifically in the pdb_get_elt_at_index function.

The vulnerability allows unused pointers to escape the UPDATE_RAW_END sanity checks in ecoff.c, potentially resulting in overflows. Additionally, the local sym fdr isymBase and csym values in the _bfd_ecoff_slurp_symbolic_info function are not properly sanity checked, which can lead to unsafe pointer usage and memory issues.

A vulnerability exists in the handling of the R_MICROMIPS_GPREL7_S2 relocation, which is intended for the 16-bit LWGP instruction (0x6400/0xfc00 match/mask encoding in `micromips_opcodes`). The relocation is specified to operate on a half-word by the howtos in elf32-mips.c, elfn32-mips.c, and elf64-mips.c, but is incorrectly subject to shuffle/unshuffle in code such as _bfd_mips_elf32_gprel16_reloc. This causes the relocation to be applied to the wrong byte: to byte 0x22 in big-endian and to byte 0x33 in little-endian, instead of the correct byte. Additionally, there are issues with REL addend extraction from section contents and with overflow checking. In gold, all of these problems are present, and it also fails to apply the required right shift by two. Functions and files affected include micromips_reloc_shuffle_p and mips_elf_calculate_relocation in elfxx-mips.c, should_shuffle_micromips_reloc and relgprel in mips.cc, and related test cases in the ld testsuite.

A vulnerability exists in objdump.c where a memcpy operation in the slurp_symtab and slurp_dynamic_symtab functions can cause a segmentation fault if symcount or dynsymcount is -1, resulting in syms or dynsyms being NULL.
A crash occurs when dissecting malformed BitTorrent packets.

A segmentation fault occurs in syms.c within the _bfd_stab_section_find_nearest_line function when "info->strs[strsize - 1] = 0;" is executed with strsize set to zero. If strsize is zero, there are no filenames in stabs, resulting in no useful information. The vulnerability is triggered when either stabsize or strsize is zero.
A heap-buffer-overflow exists in the ICMPinfo::dissectICMP function.
A heap-buffer-overflow occurs in MDNS packet dissection.
A crash occurs in the C++ implementation when processing an invalid Parquet file, due to improper handling of malformed input. This issue may also involve unnecessary memory allocation.
A heap buffer overflow exists in IEC104Stats.

A crash occurs in the C++ implementation of Apache Arrow when processing invalid IPC input due to insufficient argument checking in functions such as SliceBuffer, SliceMutableBuffer, Array::Slice, and ArrayData::Slice.
A potential out of bounds error exists in packet-quakeworld.c, where an overflow can occur while writing to a buffer.

The tvbuff_zlib function accepts negative lengths and empty buffers, which are not uncompressable. This allows a buffer overrun (read) to occur because the unsigned "avail_in" variable can become extremely large.
The asn1 code increments a buffer pointer beyond its end, which can lead to a security vulnerability.

An incorrect formatting of NSAP area addresses/address prefixes occurs when the area address/address prefix is 13 octets long. The code uses the 21st octet instead of the 13th octet, which is not part of the area address/address prefix and might either not be in the packet or might be some random other part of the packet.
A stack-use-after-return vulnerability exists in the ieee80211 code, which can lead to undefined behavior or security issues.
The gthreadedresolver does not check the header length when parsing a response, which allows reading off the end of an invalid response.

A buffer overflow (read) vulnerability exists in the DOF code due to missing sanity checks on the buffer length parsed from data. The code does not verify the buffer size before reading a value, which can lead to out-of-bounds memory access.

A vulnerability exists in the function fp_read_radix_16() where the write index is incorrectly updated during multiple writes into a word. If the last word is full and there is no more data to write, the index may be incremented unnecessarily, leading to an off-by-one error in the used value of mp_digit. This can result in an out-of-bounds read.
An edge case exists in the RSA-PSS implementation when encoding a message to a hash, which is not properly handled.
A global-buffer-overflow error occurs in the GSM RLC/MAC code due to the same root cause as gf751918.

A global-buffer-overflow error occurs in the GSM RLC/MAC dissector due to ending a structure with CSN_DESCR_END immediately after a M_NEXT_EXIST() without including another variable such as M_UINT or M_TYPE. This issue arises because the current description does not allow proper parsing, especially as the structure is reentrant, leading to a buffer overflow.

A buffer overflow vulnerability exists in elf32_arm_get_synthetic_symtab in elf32-arm.c due to insufficient validation when the .plt section size does not match the number of plt relocations. This can occur with malformed or fuzzed files, potentially leading to out-of-bounds memory access. The functions elf32_arm_plt0_size and elf32_arm_plt_size are affected, as they do not properly check if the data_size is sufficient.

An invalid cast occurs when a variable-length bytearray field is decoded as Decimal256 Arrow data in the Parquet C++ implementation. This can lead to incorrect processing of Parquet data containing Decimal256 types.
An uninitialized value is used in the makeOrientDecision() function.

ECC key sizes less than 224 bits are enabled by default, allowing the use of weak ECC curves. The option to enable smaller key sizes is controlled by `--enable-eccweakcurves` or `ECC_WEAK_CURVES`, and is automatically enabled if `WOLFSSL_MIN_ECC_BITS` is set to less than 224 bits.

An overflow occurs in the function pixCountArbInRect() in pix3_fuzzer.cc due to a bug in pixel access, where the wrong depth is used. The function is intended for use on all pix with depth less than or equal to 8.
An out of bounds access occurs when decoding the Private Extension IE in GTPv2.

A buffer overrun occurs in the zbee_sec_add_key_to_keyring function due to improper handling of the "key" variable, which is a guint8 array of ZBEE_APS_CMD_KEY_LENGTH. The code compares the pointer value instead of the actual contents of the array, leading to a security vulnerability.

The arg_show_usage() function in the code truncates long options when writing them to a fixed-sized buffer using snprintf(), resulting in options longer than the buffer size being cut off. This can cause incomplete or misleading information to be displayed for command-line options.

The SIGCOMP dissector contains multiple, severe security issues related to UDVM dissection and decompression. The display.udvm.code and decomp.msg preferences are vulnerable, and enabling them poses significant risks. Warnings are necessary when considering re-enabling these features.

A buffer overrun (read) vulnerability exists in dissect_ber_constrained_bitstring, where the length is an unsigned integer but some users, such as tvb_memdup, expect signed integers and treat negative values specially.
A vulnerability exists where the alpha channel for the merged image is not set correctly in a grayscale image.
The GetFillAlpha() function uses an uninitialized value, which can lead to unpredictable behavior or security issues.
The SDTS module passes a negative size parameter to memcpy() in some cases.
An out-of-bounds read occurs in the TLSX_CSR_Parse() function.

A vulnerability exists where the mask type in mp_cond_copy is not at least 16 bits, which causes issues when 'used' is larger than 8 bits but mp_digit is 8 bits. Additionally, when large numbers are used with 8-bit words, multiplication and squaring partial sums overflow a word, leading to incorrect behavior in these implementations.
A vulnerability exists in ReadMNGImage() where the image is magnified even if the requested magnification methods are not supported.
A vulnerability exists in the sp_mont_norm function where the normalization value is not clamped at the end, potentially leading to incorrect or insecure behavior.

A heap-use-after-free vulnerability exists in libsepol/cil when using optional blockinherit. When secilc compiles a policy where an optional block contains blockinherit statements, and one of the inherited blocks does not exist, the optional block is disabled at pass 3 (CIL_PASS_BLKIN_LINK). The function __cil_resolve_ast_last_child_helper() calls cil_tree_children_destroy() on the optional block, destroying its blockinherit statements. However, if a blockinherit node (such as (blockinherit b1)) is still referenced in its parent block's block->bi_nodes list, this list will contain a freed node. When this list is accessed in pass 4 (CIL_PASS_BLKIN_COPY), it triggers a use-after-free issue.

A missing NULL terminator in the ieee1905_reporting_policy_flags[] array in packet-ieee1905.c causes a buffer overflow. This vulnerability is triggered during the execution of functions such as proto_item_add_bitmask_tree and proto_tree_add_bitmask_with_flags in proto.c, and dissect_metric_reporting_policy and dissect_ieee1905_tlv_data in packet-ieee1905.c, leading to a global-buffer-overflow as reported by AddressSanitizer.
The sp_tohex function does not properly skip all leading zeros.
The HMAC OpenSSL API in hmac_openssl does not initialise the HMAC context on creation and does not allow a key length of 0.
NBAP contains a vulnerability where the DCH ID is used without first checking if it was initialized. This can lead to undefined behavior or security issues.
A vulnerability exists in the SIGCOMP implementation where the operand offset is not checked when accessing UDVM memory in the relevant code, potentially leading to unsafe memory access.

A vulnerability exists in libsepol/cil where the classperm list is not destroyed when resetting map perms. Map perms use the classperms field, which is a pointer to a list of classperms created and added to during the resolution of classmapping rules. Since the map permission does not own the data in the list, failing to destroy this list when the AST is reset can lead to resource management issues. The vulnerability is present when resetting a perm, as the classperms list is not properly destroyed without affecting the data in the list.
There is a potential vulnerability due to uninitialized pad bits in the function pixGetRasterData() when d < 8, which may lead to uninitialized data being used in zlib compression.

A vulnerability exists in libsepol/cil where the function cil_reset_classperms_set() resets the classpermission pointed to by the set field in struct cil_classperms_set. Since cil_classperms_set does not create the cil_classpermission, it should not reset it, as this can lead to unintended side effects. The set field is a pointer to a struct cil_classpermission that is looked up in the symbol table.

A security vulnerability exists because the input buffer can overlap, and the use of an unsafe memory copy function instead of memmove in the affected code can lead to undefined behavior or memory corruption.
A runtime error occurs in avcodec/h264_cavlc due to an out-of-bounds access with index -1 for the type 'VLC [15]'.
A vulnerability exists in avcodec/ac3dec where the band structure is not properly tracked, leading to potential out-of-array index access in certain corner cases.

A vulnerability exists where the link-layer 802.11 dissector is registered in the gre.proto table. This dissector expects to receive an 802.11 pseudoheader, but the GRE dissector provides the flags and version from the GRE header to subdissectors registered in the gre.proto table. As a result, dissectors must either expect the flags-and-version structure or ignore the pseudoheader. For 802.11, the pseudoheader contains radio information, which is not available from GRE, leading to potential issues.

A use-after-free vulnerability exists in the h225 dissector. The function next_tvb_add_handle() allocates memory in packet scope, but when dissect_h225_h225_RasMessage() handler dissects another packet without calling next_tvb_init(), next_tvb_add_handle() writes to a freed pointer. This results in a heap-use-after-free condition, as reported by AddressSanitizer, involving next_tvb_add_handle in next_tvb.c and related calls in h225.cnf and packet-h225-template.c.

A vulnerability exists in libsepol/cil where the classperms list of a classpermission rule is not destroyed when resetting the classpermission. The classperms list is created and filled in when classpermissionset rules are processed, so the classpermission rule does not own any part of the list and should not retain any of it when reset. This can lead to a heap-use-after-free condition, as observed in functions such as __cil_verify_classperms and __cil_verify_classpermission in cil_verify.c, resulting in potential crashes during policy verification.
A runtime error occurs in avcodec/mimic due to an out-of-bounds access with index 96 for the array of type 'const int8_t [64]'.
A runtime error occurs in avcodec/ac3dec due to an index of -1 being out of bounds for the type 'INTFLOAT [2]'. This issue arises because dual mono with a LFE channel is not forbidden.
A vulnerability in avcodec/dvbsubdec allows for writing beyond the end of an array due to a missing check on entry_id.
A runtime error occurs in avcodec/h264_cavlc due to an index value of -1 being out of bounds for the type 'VLC [6]'.

A vulnerability exists in DH SP math where, if SP does not support the required bit size for DH operations, the function does not return the WC_KEY_SIZE_E error as expected. This can lead to incorrect handling of key size errors in DH Agree operations.
A vulnerability exists in avcodec/hevc_ps where the c?_qp_offset_list array is accessed with an out-of-bounds index, specifically index 5 for an array of size 5, leading to a potential runtime error.
A vulnerability exists where it is assumed that the RP has the same number of channels as the image. Noise can cause the RP to have 3 additional channels, leading to potential issues.

A heap-use-after-free vulnerability exists in the function __class_reset_perm_values() in libsepol/cil. When an optional branch is destroyed after being disabled, the associated common is also destroyed. However, the reset code still attempts to access the number of common permissions in order to revert the class permissions to their original values, leading to a use-after-free condition. This issue is triggered during the processing of certain CIL policy constructs involving optional blocks and classcommon statements.

A heap buffer overflow (out-of-bound read) occurs in cil_print_recursive_blockinherit in libsepol/cil when the CIL compiler encounters a recursive blockinherit with an optional block. This happens because cil_print_recursive_blockinherit() assumes that all nodes are either CIL_BLOCK or CIL_BLOCKINHERIT, leading to incorrect handling of other block kinds.

A dangling reference vulnerability occurs in an extreme out-of-memory condition where, if memory is exhausted to the point that the Postscript error handler cannot run properly, references to arrays recording the stacks' content in $error can persist until final garbage collection, even though the arrays themselves have been freed by the end-of-job restore. This results in invalid references remaining in $error.

An out-of-bound read occurs in the CIL compiler (libsepol/cil) when processing a file context pattern ending with a backslash ("\") in the cil_post_fc_fill_data() function. When the function encounters a backslash at the end of the string, it reads beyond the NUL terminator, leading to a heap-buffer-overflow. This issue is triggered by file context entries such as (filecon "\" any ()).
A vulnerability exists where memory devices are allowed to change media sizes, resolutions, or other parameters that affect the size of the raster memory allocation.

A vulnerability exists in the OSITP dissector where subdissectors are called even if there is no data in the packet. None of the current heuristic dissectors for "cotp" accept empty packets, so invoking subdissectors in this case is unnecessary and could lead to unintended behavior.

In libsepol/cil, there are six instances during CIL policy building or resolution where an error is detected, but SEPOL_OK is incorrectly returned instead of SEPOL_ERR. This allows the policy compiler to continue processing when it should terminate with an error.

A vulnerability exists in the CIL compiler (libsepol/cil) where a failure in the cil_fill_list() function is not properly propagated, allowing compilation to continue after encountering an "Invalid syntax" error. This can lead to a NULL dereference READ when processing malformed policy statements such as (optional o (validatetrans x (eq t3 (a ())))), resulting in further errors like "Bad expression tree for constraint" and "Bad validatetrans declaration."

A vulnerability exists in the TLS dissector where it can be called via multiple entry points, such as directly (e.g., EAP-TTLS/EAP-PEAP with an explicit dissector name) or through dissector tables. The TCP and SCTP dissectors pass a data parameter of a different type, leading to type confusion and resulting in crashes.
A vulnerability exists in the TLS Hmac_UpdateFinal_CT() function where truncated MACs are not properly handled.

A vulnerability exists in the URI scope parsing code in guri, where the parser can read past the end of a URI if it encounters an incorrect %-escaped character. This issue affects the handling of zone ID syntax as defined in RFC 6874, which amends RFC 3986. The vulnerability also impacts the correctness of network-address tests related to zone IDs.
The function in avcodec/mlpdec leaves invalid values in the matrix_out_ch[] array on error, which results in a runtime error due to an out-of-bounds index access (index 12 for type 'uint8_t [8]').
The avcodec/mlpdec component leaves an invalid num_primitive_matrices value in the context, which results in a runtime error: index 8 out of bounds for type 'uint8_t [8]'.
Converting an empty rect to an irect does not preserve the coordinates.

A vulnerability exists in fz_paint_image_imp() where, if both scissor and bbox are fz_empty_rect, the variables w and h are set to FZ_MIN_INF_RECT and x and y to FZ_MAX_INF_RECT, respectively. When subtracting x from w (and y from h), this can cause an underflow (e.g., FZ_MIN_INF_RECT - FZ_MAX_INF_RECT == 128). The existing check for w/h being less than 0 is insufficient to prevent this underflow.
A vulnerability exists due to pointer aliasing issues when passing the scissor parameter by pointer instead of by value. This can lead to unexpected behavior or security risks.
A buffer overflow vulnerability exists due to accessing past the end of the xref_index.
The gdal_translate_fuzzer function allows situations where excessive memory allocation occurs, potentially leading to a security vulnerability.

A vulnerability exists in gdatetime where NAN is allowed as a number of seconds in a GDateTime. Since NAN never compares TRUE against anything, the limit checks `seconds < 0.0 || seconds >= 60.0` do not trigger, allowing invalid values to pass through.
A buffer-overflow READ occurs in the toLanguateTag function.
A vulnerability exists in the parsing of raw profile reading that allows for heap read overruns due to insufficient bounds checking.
A vulnerability exists in ReadMNGImage() where the mng_LOOP chunk is not validated to be at least 5 bytes long.
The gdate component does not validate input as UTF-8 before parsing, allowing non-UTF-8 data to be processed. Dates are expected to be valid UTF-8.
A vulnerability exists where PDFium allows page width and height to be less than 1, which causes libvips severe indigestion.
A vulnerability exists where the input buffer is not checked before being passed to libheif.
A security vulnerability exists where the dateStyle and timeStyle parameters in the fuzzer are not limited to only valid enum values.
A security vulnerability exists in Calendar::set where the function does not check if the field is valid.
A vulnerability exists where a buffer is not reset, leading to the use of an uninitialized value.
An index out of bound read occurs in the AVCBIN component.

A vulnerability exists in the WCP protocol dissector where an overflow can occur due to a buffer being too long. This issue arises from improper handling of buffer lengths, leading to a potential buffer overflow error in the WCP buffer.

A vulnerability exists in the DNS SRV record handling where a malformed packet that does not follow the "_Service._Proto.Name" format and provides a zero-length name causes wmem_strsplit to return NULL, leading to a null pointer dereference.
A vulnerability exists in srvloc where the buffer index is not properly checked, which can lead to a heap overflow.

A buffer overflow occurs in the RTCP dissector for transport-cc when the packet status chunks cover more packets than indicated by the packet status count field, causing data to be written past the end of the buffer.
A vulnerability exists in the val_to_str() function in the rtps module due to improper formatting and lack of explanatory messages, which may lead to unclear or incorrect output.

The CDMA2000 code contains improper offset handling, where the pointer to the offset is incremented instead of the offset itself. This leads to incorrect memory access and various related problems in the affected statements.

An out-of-bounds write vulnerability exists in the utf8ToUtf16() function in poppler/UTF.cc. This issue is introduced by a recent regression and is detected by Valgrind as an invalid write of size 2, occurring immediately after a block of allocated memory. The vulnerability can be triggered during PDF processing, as seen in the call stack involving utf8ToUtf16(), utf8ToUtf16WithBom(), and Lexer::getObj().

A vulnerability exists due to incorrect size calculations in the tables listing UTF-8 and Boolean properties, where the elements are guints rather than guint16's. This discrepancy can lead to issues on systems where the size of guints differs from guint16's.
A stack-use-after-scope vulnerability exists in the uloc component.

A vulnerability in the COBS decoding of the mstp module allows for a buffer overflow, leading to a potential crash (denial of service) due to a large buffer overrun (read) when the "MS/TP Length" is smaller than 3. In this case, an integer overflow results in a large unsigned number. Additionally, a buffer overflow (write) occurs when the "code" (length) octet is 0, which is illegal and causes an integer overflow. With a specially crafted encoded CRC-32K value, this can result in writing 255 bytes past the end of the buffer (xoring the octets with 0x55). The vulnerability is related to the handling of the "length" parameter and its interpretation in the decoding process.

A buffer overflow vulnerability exists in the DNS code due to an off-by-one error when writing to a buffer. The "maxname" variable represents the size of the buffer, including the "null label" (NUL byte), but the code writes past the end of the buffer. This can result in a write buffer overflow.
An off-by-one error occurs in xcsl during premature exit.
An incorrect memory read occurs when the locale is bogus, leading to an illegal read and a memory issue.

A vulnerability exists where formats that might appear inside a generic archive do not call _bfd_generic_close_and_cleanup, leading to stale entries in the archive element lookup htab that point to freed and potentially reused memory. This can result in segmentation faults when the archive is closed. In pdb.c, the functions pdb_close_and_cleanup and pdb_archive_p are involved, with pdb_close_and_cleanup needing to be defined as _bfd_generic_close_and_cleanup and tdata needing to be set up for the bfd_archive format.
A buffer overflow bug exists in the Dutch accented IJ titlecase handling in ICU, specifically affecting the processing of certain character sequences.
A vulnerability exists in ieee80211 due to incorrect sizeof usage in the AID column, and the string version of the AID column does not allow proper filtering.
A vulnerability exists in the ani module where riffSizeData is not checked for the correct size before performing the quint32_le cast, potentially leading to incorrect behavior or security issues.
An out of bounds copy occurs in the RF4CE code, potentially leading to memory corruption.
A heap buffer overflow occurs in addr_resolv when fewer than 6 bytes are passed to ws_manuf_lookup_str().
A crash occurs in epan/dissectors/packet-btl2cap.c at line 2929 due to keys added to wmem_tree not having exactly the same length.
A vulnerability exists in the ORAN FH CUS Ext11 implementation where improper handling of the array index occurs if there are 0 bundles, potentially leading to out-of-bounds access.
A vulnerability exists in packet-gsm_rlp where the code reads beyond the captured length when computing the FCS.
A vulnerability exists in epan where a conversation key is not allocated, potentially leading to issues with conversation handling.

The vulnerability in ALP involves improper memory management due to the use of memcpy instead of tvb_memcpy, and an incorrect while() loop over numts. This can lead to potential memory handling issues in the affected code.
An out of bounds access to the snmp_PDUs_vals array occurs in the SNMP code.
A vulnerability exists in the ieee1722 dissector where the payload_length field is used without validating its correctness, potentially leading to incorrect processing or security issues.
A vulnerability exists in the RRC code where a freed wmem_strbuf structure is used, which can lead to use-after-free issues.
A vulnerability exists in ReadOneJNGImage() where the function does not report a useful exception when a JNG file fails to provide the necessary image chunks to allocate the color image.
A heap write overflow occurs in the PathInfo array within the ConvertPrimitiveToPath() function.
A vulnerability exists in the ReadMNGImage() function where the length of the DISC chunk is not validated to ensure it is evenly divisible by 2.
A read heap buffer overflow occurs in EHdr when nbits is less than 8.
A stack read overflow occurs in MagickGetToken() when parsing a URL.
An off-by-one error in the loop bounds check in the TranslateTextEx() function allows a one-byte stack write overflow.
A vulnerability in DrawDashPolygon() allows reading beyond the end of the dash pattern array.
A security vulnerability exists in the DrawImage() function due to insufficient MVG parser validations.
A vulnerability exists in the TraceEllipse() function where arithmetic overflow can occur when computing the number of points to allocate for an ellipse.
A potential buffer overflow exists in the string_unescape() function in the json module, which can be triggered by invalid input.

The 'compressed' string in the lzxpress plain round-trip fuzzer can be approximately 9/8 the size of the decompressed string, but insufficient memory is allocated for this in the fuzz target. Additionally, there is no check when this allocation fails.
A vulnerability exists in ReadMIFFImage() where EOF is not detected when reading using ReadBlobZC(), leading to a potential heap read overflow.

A vulnerability exists due to a compiler warning about conversion from 'double' to 'int32_t' in the use of kOneDay, which is defined as 1.0 * U_MILLIS_PER_DAY, instead of using U_MILLIS_PER_DAY directly.

The isMatchAtCPBoundary function in ICU contains a vulnerability where it uses an uninitialized value, leading to potential undefined behavior. This issue is detected by fuzz testing and can be observed in the custrtst test suite.
OGRCreateMultiPatch() allows invalid geometry conversion, leading to a security vulnerability.
A null pointer dereference occurs in the DXF module when the DXF_MAX_BSPLINE_CONTROL_POINTS limit is reached.
A null pointer dereference occurs in the ISCE component.

A security vulnerability exists in smbd where file_attributes are overridden with unix_mode in the VFS, potentially leading to incorrect file permission handling. This issue is present in open.c, where internal logic still uses this override.
A vulnerability exists in the TCP implementation where the absence of a SACK range check allows writing past the ends of the sack_left_edge and sack_right_edge arrays.
A vulnerability exists in FoFiTrueType::parse where parsing does not succeed if tables are missing.

A vulnerability exists in nmblib within the handle_name_ptrs() function, where if *offset is equal to length - 1, the code reads ubuf[(*offset)+1] as the lower bits of the new *offset. This results in undefined behaviour, although the value is checked against the valid range and does not allow reading further beyond that one byte.
PAMDataset performs an illegal down_cast to GDALPamRasterBand, which can lead to a security vulnerability.

A vulnerability exists in the fuzz_ndr_X function in lib/fuzzing where the st buffer is not initialised before use. An NDR pull of a function fills in either the in. or out. elements of the structure, but never both. Some structures have size_is() in the out. that reference the in. elements, which can lead to uninitialised data being accessed. The fuzzing handler relies on the in-side of the buffer being zeroed, but without initialisation, this assumption is violated, potentially leading to undefined behavior.
A vulnerability exists in RMF where an invalid JPEG codestream can cause a crash.
A vulnerability exists in librpc where ndr_pull_charset_to_null() does not properly check string lengths.

A vulnerability exists in idl/drsblobs where the number of schedules in a struct is incorrectly overwritten to 1, even when the struct actually contains zero or two schedules. This can lead to incorrect handling of schedule data.
A potential read heap buffer overflow exists in shpopen.c within the SHPRewindObject() function when handling single-point polygons.

A use-after-free vulnerability exists in librpc due to incorrect talloc hierarchy management for ndr_compression_state. The unnecessary complexity in generic_mszip_free() and the lack of proper memory tree creation can lead to memory being freed while still in use.

A vulnerability exists in lib/replace where the functions strlcat and strlcpy are used without ensuring they are properly declared in <string.h>. This leads to implicit declaration errors in C99, as seen in replace.c and getarg.c, because the presence of symbol names in libc is not sufficient without checking for their declarations. This can cause compilation failures when building the code.
A heap buffer overflow exists in the OGR_GMT component.
A security vulnerability exists due to the use of RasterIO(GF_Read...) within the IWriteBlock function in the read pipeline, which may lead to unintended data exposure or manipulation.

The ieee1905 reassembly code assumes that address sizes are always 6 bytes, leading to a failing read when processing addresses of different sizes. The code uses a local buffer based on this assumption instead of dynamically allocating memory according to the actual address size from the structures.
A vulnerability exists in the btle code where the acl_data variable is not initialised, which can lead to a wild pointer dereference.
A vulnerability in BitStuffer2::Decode() allows index out of bound access.

A vulnerability exists in the rtps dissector where wmem_allocated memory is stored in pinfo->private_table, which is created with free functions (g_free) that are incompatible with wmem allocations. This can lead to memory management issues due to the collision between g_free and wmem allocations.
A heap buffer overflow occurs in the idn component due to lack of index checking before use.

A vulnerability exists in the VJ compression implementation where, when handling uncompressed packets, there are missing bounds checks before allocating or reading memory. The code allocates memory based on the entire packet contents rather than limiting it to the size of the IP header plus the maximum needed size of the TCP header. There is also a lack of verification for IPv4 before processing. When handling compressed packets, bounds checks are missing when calculating the size of the compression header. Additionally, the calculation of syn+ack values uses the captured length instead of the reported length, which may not match what the sender uses. These issues can lead to potential memory allocation and processing errors.

The SkCanvas::kIsOpaque_SaveLayerFlag serves as a performance-only hint and is not used by anyone except fuzzers. Fuzzers can exploit this flag to allocate uninitialized memory and treat it as opaque, leading to blending of uninitialized pixels and other unintended behaviors.
The code does not check the length of marker before reading it, which can lead to a security vulnerability.
A heap overflow exists in the UnpackWPGRaster() function in WPG.
The EXIF parser does not skip unsupported or invalid format 0, which can lead to a security vulnerability.
The path deserialization process does not check for sufficient data, which can lead to security vulnerabilities.
A bug in SkAnimatedImage::decodeNextFrame leads to uninitialized memory access, which can result in undefined behavior and potential security vulnerabilities.
The GenerateEXIFAttribute() function lacks validations, which allows a heap buffer overflow to occur.
The vulnerability occurs in drawTextRSXform where bad xform input is not properly handled.
A vulnerability in avcodec/tiertexseqv arises from not setting fixed dimensions, instead depending on the demuxer to do so, which leads to out-of-array access.
avcodec/aacps contains undefined behavior due to the existence of a potentially invalid pointer intermediate.
A vulnerability exists in ReadTIFFImage() where exceptions from QuantumTransferMode() for planar TIFF are not handled immediately, potentially leading to unhandled exceptions.
A vulnerability exists in the QuantumTransferMode() function where CIE Log images with an alpha channel are not supported.
A vulnerability exists in ReadTIFFImage() where the function does not use DirectClass mode when utilizing libtiff RGBA reader interfaces.
The vulnerability occurs in the XCF load_level() function, where the 'tile_image' resource is not freed before returning an exception, potentially leading to a memory leak.
A vulnerability exists in ReadMATImage() where the function does not properly quit if image scanlines are not fully populated due to an exception.
A vulnerability exists in the ReadTIFFImage() function where the opacity channel is not assured to be initialized in the RGBAStrippedMethod case.
A vulnerability exists in ReadMIFFImage() where zero-length deflate-encoded rows in MIFF version 0 are not detected and rejected.
A vulnerability exists in the ReadTIFFImage() function where the alpha channel is incorrectly disassociated for images that do not have a photometric value of PHOTOMETRIC_RGB.
A vulnerability exists in WritePDBImage() where the input scanline is not cleared, potentially exposing data due to a decoder bug.
A vulnerability exists in ExtractTileJPG() where JPEG tiles are not enforced to be read by the JPEG coder.
The WebP encoder in TIFF only supports 8 bits per sample, leading to a security vulnerability when handling images with other bit depths.
A vulnerability exists in the DrawPrimitive() function where arithmetic overflow can occur when converting computed coordinates from 'double' to 'long'.
A vulnerability exists in pathmeasure where failure to evaluate the conic is not properly checked.
If makeOffset fails and this is not detected, the imagefilter might not write to all of the pixels it claims it will, resulting in uninitialized memory.

A use-of-uninitialized-value vulnerability exists in SkPictureShader::onMakeContext. The function SkPictureShader::refBitmapShader is expected to always initialize the scale adjust vector when returning a non-null shader, but the code path returning EmptyShader does not perform this initialization.
A vulnerability in avcodec/midivid allows an out-of-array read due to a missing check on the vector index.

A heap overflow occurs in the 'ih264d_read_coeff4x4_cabac' function in mvcdec when parsing certain erroneous bitstreams. The vulnerability arises because the slice data may require more parsing than indicated by the distance between successive start codes, primarily due to the NEXTBITS macro, which reads 4 additional bytes from the bitstream buffer. This can lead to out-of-bounds memory access if the buffer is not sufficiently large, especially for 4x4 transform units and when handling chroma bytes for 4:2:0/4:2:2 formats.
A vulnerability exists where OP_XML_REPLACE_NODE does not perform the same check as OP_XML_UNLINK_NODE, leading to improper unlinking of DTD when replacing nodes.
A vulnerability exists in icaltypes.c within the icalreqstattype_from_string() function, where memory is allocated for an empty status.debug string.
The Wasm loader does not check that, in a code entry, the code size matches the size of vec(locals) plus expr, and that expr ends with the opcode end.
A vulnerability exists in tpm2 where an out-of-range command code is not checked before being used to access an index in an array in a debug statement, potentially leading to out-of-bounds access.
The Wasm loader does not check that, in a code entry, the code size matches the size of vec(locals) plus expr, and that expr ends with the opcode end.

A vulnerability exists where the code attempts to create embedded reference sequences for CRAM containers with reads mapped to chr -1 (i.e., unmapped). The embed_ref option is not permitted in multi-ref mode and is nonsensical for entirely unmapped data. The function cram_generate_reference() can be called without checking if c->ref_id < 0, leading to potential issues. Additional checks elsewhere are necessary to avoid related problems.
The elf_lookup function in elf.cpp does not defend against a bad chain in the hash table, which can lead to a security vulnerability.
A use-of-uninitialized-value vulnerability exists in gpsd/packet.c and packet_parse.c, where uninitialized values may be used during packet parsing.
A vulnerability exists where unsuccessful attribute conversions do not result in an error, potentially allowing invalid or unexpected data to be processed.

A vulnerability exists where compression/transformation destination buffers are not allocated using tj3Alloc() and ZERO_BUFFERS is not defined for MSan builds, potentially leading to uninitialized memory usage.

The Rar5 reader reads the name size, then reads the name, and only afterwards checks whether the name size exceeds the maximum allowed. This allows for very large memory allocations to read a name, potentially leading to excessive memory usage.
A use-of-uninitialized-value vulnerability exists in gpsd/packet.c and packet_parse.c.

A buffer under-read occurs in the nxt_inet_addr() function in socket code when processing a listener address that starts with a colon (":"), or any address where the first character is a colon. If the length variable, which represents the position of the colon in the string, is 0, the code under-reads the addr->start buffer in the following check: if (nxt_slow_path(*(buf + length - 1) == '.')). Any address that starts with a colon is invalid in Unit configuration.
A vulnerability exists in vm.c (OP_STRCAT) where mrb_str_concat may call the VM recursively, which can lead to reallocation of the call-info stack.
A mistake in internal calculations of limits when reading DWARF5 .debug_names in src/lib/libdwarf/dwarf_debugnames.c introduces a security vulnerability.
A use-after-free vulnerability exists in the function gf_m2ts_es_del.
The `FileTest` module is incorrectly defined as a class, which may lead to unexpected behavior or security issues due to improper module usage.
A buffer overflow exists in the MD3Loader, which can lead to potential security issues.

A mistake in 2021 introduces an error by adding to an end-section pointer in .debug_abbrev within src/lib/libdwarf/dwarf_util.c. This bug is exposed by heavily fuzzed test objects, allowing -fsanitize to detect the issue.
A vulnerability exists because the `Kernel#p` method is implemented in mruby-print instead of kernel.c, making it harder to skip `p` in the debugger.
A security vulnerability exists in the ELF stubs where the placement of DT_STRTAB and DT_SYMTAB differs for Go language binaries, potentially leading to incorrect handling in the p_lx_elf.cpp file.
A vulnerability exists where zero width or height images are not checked, potentially leading to issues when processing such images.
A heap buffer overflow occurs in svcdec when the decoder display dimensions do not match the subset sequence dimensions.
The decodeGainmapMetadata() function allows out-of-bounds access due to subtraction between unsigned types, which results in large values because of wrap-around behavior.

A vulnerability exists in the `Dataset::IsTlvValid()` method where the Active/Pending Timestamp and Delay Timer TLVs are not validated for minimum required length, allowing datasets with invalid TLVs to be accepted when set on a device.

A vulnerability exists in libselinux/fuzz where inputs with empty or non-existent separated trailing data are not properly handled. The size is not initialized to 0, and related code may be called even when the size is zero, potentially leading to unexpected behavior. This affects the code introduced in the selabel_file(5) fuzzer.
A change in icalparser.c intended to address a Coverity issue introduces a vulnerability that can be triggered by fuzzing.
Enabling zlib and liblzma with MSan in fuzzing introduces a vulnerability because these libraries require instrumented builds to work correctly with MemorySanitizer.

A vulnerability exists in nxt_tstr_test() where error messages are created using nxt_sprintf() without ensuring they are nul-terminated. These error messages are later used with the '%s' format specifier, which expects a nul-terminated string. Since nxt_sprintf() does not nul-terminate by default and requires the '%Z' specifier to add a '\0' at the end, this can lead to use of uninitialized memory and potential security issues in functions such as nxt_conf_vldt_error, nxt_conf_vldt_var, and nxt_conf_vldt_if in unit/src/nxt_conf_validation.c.

The usage of periodic_adv_info_tree in btle allows insertion of two different types into the same tree, leading to potential memory corruption. Connection info should be the only type inserted into the periodic adv info tree.
A potential heap overflow exists in polygonToCellsExperimental due to under-estimation.

A buffer overflow vulnerability exists in QPDF::read_xrefEntry due to missing validation for the first end-of-line character. Overlong f1 or f2 entries consisting only of zeros can trigger this buffer overflow.
A vulnerability exists in fuzz/ParseFuzzer.cpp where the maxChars input for the call to uriToStringW is not properly handled.

A vulnerability exists in clist playback where an invalid or "insane" CTM (current transformation matrix) is not properly checked, potentially leading to unintended behavior. If the CTM is nonsensical, it can result in a zero size transformation.

A vulnerability in mem_planar_put_image_slow causes a segmentation fault (SEGV) due to double addition of the offset to input pointers, leading to buffer overruns for images that do not start at (0,0). Additionally, there is a risk of missing stray pixels at the end of rows.

A security vulnerability exists where destination buffers for compression/transformation are not allocated using tj3Alloc() and ZERO_BUFFERS is not defined for MSan builds, potentially leading to uninitialized memory usage.

A heap-buffer overflow exists in the text_to_stream function due to incorrect use of the viewer stat stack, which can result in accessing a state beyond the end of the stack in extreme cases. This issue arises from tracking the stack like a graphics state parameter within the pdfwrite device structure.

The vulnerability occurs when destination buffers are allocated using malloc() instead of tj3Alloc() (which calls calloc() when ZERO_BUFFERS is defined) in compression, decompression, or transform operations. If such an operation fails, the buffer checksum—used to prevent compiler optimization—may depend on uninitialized values in the destination buffer, leading to potential issues detected by memory sanitizers.
The vulnerability occurs when replaygain application is not turned off when it is impossible to apply, even though a warning is thrown. This can lead to unintended behavior in the affected code.
A call to pdf_dict_getl() in the code lacks a terminating NULL in the dictionary key lookup path, which can cause issues during compilation, particularly when using clang-17.

A security vulnerability exists where destination buffers for compression/transformation are not allocated using tj3Alloc() and ZERO_BUFFERS is not defined for MSan builds, potentially leading to uninitialized memory usage.
A potential buffer read overflow exists in btf_ext_parse_info() in libbpf when accessing the BTF.ext core_relo header without ensuring its presence, which can lead to out-of-bounds memory access.

A vulnerability exists where the encoding handler is not always consumed when creating output buffers in the io module. The encoding handler may also not be freed in error cases. The function xmlAllocOutputBufferInternal is redundant as it is identical to xmlAllocOutputBuffer.
A bug in QPDFWriter::preserveObjectStreams allows QPDF::getCompressibleObjSet to delete objects from the object cache when there are multiple entries for the same object id.
A vulnerability exists in wasm_loader and wasm_mini_loader due to incorrect table index calculations.
A vulnerability exists in p_mach.cpp where too-short Mach_command structures are not properly detected, and insufficient care is taken during recovery, potentially leading to security issues.

A vulnerability exists in the FAC payload writing path where the bit-writing logic is not properly skipped when no bits are to be written. This can lead to unintended behavior due to the lack of an appropriate check in the bit-writing logic.

A vulnerability exists in the de-compression of ELF shared libraries due to improper resetting of ph.method on each b_info.b_method. The file_image[] is not consistently treated as ReadOnly, and fi->seek()+read() is not subsumed. There is also unsafe usage of lowmem[0, +xct_off) for changing values, and issues occur during the operation of un_DT_INIT() in the affected files p_lx_elf.cpp, p_lx_elf.h, and p_unix.cpp.
The Pl_AES_PDF constructor does not validate the key length.
A vulnerability exists in mruby-bigint's mpz_init_set_str function, where a string starting with `+` is not properly skipped, potentially causing silent errors that may lead to serious issues later.

A vulnerability exists in the CRAM encoder where negative POS fields are not properly protected against. The code checks pos against the ref end and then fetches `&ref[apos]` to get the reference, which can result in understepping the array. This allows for out-of-bounds POS values to cause errors due to lack of proper input sanity checks.

A vulnerability exists where incorrect aber values are not properly cleaned, and insufficient extra data is allocated to the image, leading to a potential buffer overrun when processing specially crafted test images.

A vulnerability exists where stack consistency is compromised if the `frame_offset` increases and becomes equal to the `frame_offset_boundary` after the last assignment within the for loop, due to insufficient space for dummy offsets.
A use-after-free vulnerability exists in the AST `repr()` function.
A vulnerability exists in core: parser/sdp where the code does not check if it is still before the end of the value, potentially leading to out-of-bounds access.

The accept and decline hooks in the code are not properly initialized, causing their pointer values to appear set in downstream code when they are actually unset. This can lead to incorrect behavior due to the uninitialized state of these hooks.
A heap-buffer-overflow error exists in the functions compileRule and _lou_extParseChars.
A vulnerability exists where zero width or height images are not checked, potentially leading to issues when processing such images.
A vulnerability exists where the system does not error out if an attribute conversion is unsuccessful.

Referencing into a bad devn_params struct inappropriately allows dereferencing the struct directly instead of retrieving it using the device call, as indicated by comments in the code. This can result in obtaining a random value for the black component, leading to out-of-bounds memory access.
The return value of zho_build_properties_ex() is passed to ZVAL_ARR(), which sets the IS_TYPE_REFCOUNTED flag. Returning &zend_empty_array can cause a crash later when trying to dtor the zval.

A vulnerability exists where malformed input files can cause the archive start offset to become negative. This issue arises due to insufficient validation of the input, potentially leading to unexpected behavior.

A vulnerability exists where malformed input files can cause the archive start offset to become negative. This issue arises due to insufficient validation of the input, potentially leading to unexpected behavior.
The function gf_hevc_compute_ref_list() lacks sufficient length checks, which can lead to security vulnerabilities.
A security vulnerability exists in dash_client where the length of strings is not properly checked, potentially leading to buffer overflows or memory corruption.
A vulnerability exists where the nesting depth is not checked before pushing a clip mark, which might cause the nesting depth to step outside the layer/clip stack.
A vulnerability exists where the nesting depth is not checked before pushing a clip mark, which might allow the nesting depth to step outside the layer/clip stack.

A vulnerability exists in pdfwrite where the code attempts to restore the viewer state without first checking that the viewer depth is at least 1. The restore operation does not perform its own depth check before using the value, which can lead to incorrect behavior or potential security issues.

A heap-use-after-free vulnerability exists in attr_free due to zend_hash_get_current_key() not returning a string with incremented refcount, leading to an incorrect release. This causes a use-after-free when the attribute is destroyed. The issue is not detected when object_init_with_constructor() is used only with interned strings.

A vulnerability exists in the openpgp module where, during RSA key pair generation using PKCS#15 init, the driver accepts responses relevant to ECC keys. This causes further processing in pkcs15-init to fail or access invalid parts of structures.
A vulnerability exists where, if there is a leading minus sign, the parsing in the relevant function still advances even when it is not an infinity value, which is not the intended behavior.
The starcos_gen_key() function does not check the SW2 value when SW1 is 0x90. As a result, errors are not propagated and key generation proceeds with unallocated values.
The fuzz-eval target in the code lacks a necessary return statement, which can lead to unintended behavior or security issues.
The vulnerability is a use of uninitialized memory in the function hScale16To15_c(), which occurs due to alloc_lines() not clearing allocated memory in swscale/slice.
A buffer overflow occurs in the openpgp code when writing the fingerprint. The surrounding code does not return an error when a step fails, but only logs it.
The ff_iamf_read_packet() function in avformat/iamf_reader uses uninitialized memory due to lack of initialization of the padding variable and missing checks on read operations.
The function in avcodec/rv60dec does not initialize the slice gb with the actually allocated size, which results in an out-of-array access vulnerability.

The vulnerability occurs in tools/target_dec_fuzzer where missing slices can have unpredictable content due to the use of uninitialized values. The buffer allocation does not zero the memory, leading to potential use of uninitialized data, which does not match the behavior of production code that zeros these buffers. This can result in unpredictable or insecure behavior during decoding.

A vulnerability exists in tiffload where the return code of TIFFReadRawTile is not respected, potentially leading to improper handling of tile data. This issue is related to changes introduced in commit 7b47b07.
The vulnerability is due to the use of an uninitialized variable, predefined_SLConfigDescriptor_seen, in avformat/mpegts.

The avcodec/get_buffer code for audio uses uninitialized memory, particularly affecting the AAC/USAC/SBR code which reads uninitialized values. This issue arises because memory allocated for audio buffers is not zero-initialized, unlike the approach used for video. Functions and files involved include avcodec/get_buffer and the handling of audio buffers.

A vulnerability exists in avformat/iamf_parse where parsing the AAC DecoderConfigDescriptor does not properly account for both the tags and the vlc value that follows, due to not using ff_mp4_read_descr(). This can lead to incorrect parsing of the descriptor.
A use of uninitialized value vulnerability exists in avcodec/hevc/hevcdec due to qp_y_tab not being initialized.
The function ff_parse_mpeg2_descriptor() in avformat/wtvdec reads over uninitialized memory in the variable buf, leading to a use of uninitialized memory vulnerability.
The vulnerability occurs when the data size is not properly checked against the end of the RIFF chunk, which can lead to out-of-bounds reads.
A hidden variable named myerr in the my_error_exit function can cause unexpected behavior or security issues.

A vulnerability exists where the extraction of the user-agent from plain text in (G)QUIC versions is attempted, despite the user agent no longer being available in plain text since the end of 2021. This affects code that relies on outdated assumptions about user-agent accessibility in QUIC.

The vulnerability occurs in tools/target_dec_fuzzer where missing slices can have unpredictable content due to the use of uninitialized values. The buffer allocation does not match the production code, which zeros these buffers, leading to potential security issues.
The VP9RawSuperframeIndex structure in avcodec/cbs_vp9 is not initialized, which leads to a use-of-uninitialized-value vulnerability.
